G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of care to avoid creating hazards that foreseeably could cause harm.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses duty generally and acknowledges that landowners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care, but its core holding is that this particular defendant *did not* owe the plaintiff a duty to avoid the specific roadway hazard (i.e., to construct a bridge, light, or alter Route 1A). The court expressly rejects expanding a landowner’s duty to cover hazards on adjacent public highways it does not control. Thus, the case limits, rather than supports, the claimed broad duty to avoid creating foreseeable hazards in this context.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway. … In this case, Westwood did not fail to exercise reasonable care in the use of its land, nor was there any condition on its land that created an unreasonable risk to users of Route 1A.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.raw_text: Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (property owners owe a duty of reasonable care)
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Defendant’s decision to store a large ladder unsecured, leaning against a wooden fence near the shared driveway, created an unreasonable risk of harm that Defendant knew or should have known posed a foreseeable danger to Plaintiff and her property.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurrence discussing the abandonment of the invitee/licensee distinction and critiquing the treatment of trespassers. It does not address, factually or legally, the specific situation of storing an unsecured ladder or the foreseeability of harm from such storage. While Mounsey more generally stands for a duty of reasonable care owed by property owners, nothing in this quoted text establishes or applies that duty to the described ladder scenario, so it does not support the detailed proposition claimed.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. ... The very effort at dry classification and differentation puts the emphasis at the wrong places."

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.raw_text: Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153 (2013) (negligence exists where a duty of reasonable care is violated)
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.proposition: Defendant breached his duty of care by failing to secure the ladder despite Plaintiff’s repeated warnings about its risk of falling and causing damage.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses negligence, duty, breach, and foreseeability, but it does not involve any facts about a ladder, securing a ladder, or a defendant ignoring a plaintiff’s repeated warnings about a specific risk. Instead, it concerns a landowner’s duty to remedy an open and obvious danger created by placing a trampoline next to a shallow pool. Thus, while the case is relevant for the general concept that negligence exists when a duty of reasonable care is breached, it does not specifically support the proposition about failing to secure a ladder after repeated warnings.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.relevant_excerpt: “‘Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury.’ Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 742-743 (1995). An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was the direct and proximate cause of the damages to Plaintiff’s vehicle.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion in Jupin v. Kask addresses elements of negligence generally, with the court focusing on whether the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care regarding storage of firearms. It expressly leaves breach, proximate cause, and damages to the jury and does not hold that the defendant’s breach was the direct and proximate cause of any specific damage, let alone damage to a vehicle. The cited page thus does not support the proposition that the defendant’s breach was the direct and proximate cause of damage to the plaintiff’s vehicle.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury.”

Julian v. Randazzo, 380 Mass. 391, 396 (.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages, including her insurance deductible and car rental expenses, were foreseeable consequences of Defendant’s failure to secure the ladder.
Julian v. Randazzo, 380 Mass. 391, 396 (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Julian v. Randazzo concerns police use of deadly force, admissibility of a police investigative report, and jury instructions on justification and probable cause. It does not discuss damages, foreseeability, insurance deductibles, rental-car expenses, or any consequential damages analysis. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that a plaintiff’s deductible and rental expenses were foreseeable consequences of a defendant’s failure to secure a ladder.
Julian v. Randazzo, 380 Mass. 391, 396 (.relevant_excerpt: In this setting, the judge’s charge properly informed the jury that an officer authorized to make an arrest may use “such force as is reasonably necessary to effect the arrest,” and that the use of deadly force is subject to the additional limitations stated. It was within the judge’s discretion to decide that the additional elaboration requested by the plaintiff as to what constitutes excessive force might have been confusing rather than helpful.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696-97.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696-97.support_reasoning: The case does not hold that the defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence; it affirms summary judgment for the defendant because plaintiffs failed to prove causation and possibly duty. The opinion explains that there was no evidence linking any act or omission by the defendant to the scaffolding collapse, and thus the negligence claims could not succeed. Therefore, this decision is authority for rejecting negligence liability on these facts, not for establishing that the conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696-97.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care… Causation is an essential element of that proof. … [T]he record reflects that the plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them….”
